description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 25, 2020: With Bulletin N. 90, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended a meeting with EU Health Commissioner, Stella Kyriakides, and the Ministers of Health of those countries bordering with Italy: Austria, France, Slovenia and Switzerland. The Ministers of Health of Germany and Croatia also took part in the meeting. The aim of the meeting was to share and discuss information about the epidemiological situations of COVID-19 in the States. Issues about travelling and movement of goods between countries were also discussed.

description: On June 10, 2020, Science and Education Minister Blazenka Divjak on Wednesday presented a draft distance education action plan for the next school year. The plan  comprises three scenarios: : mostly live education, with the possibility of distance education for some students; a mixed model combining live and distance education, with both containing elements of e-learning; and mostly distance education, for the autumn semester depending on the epidemiological situation.

description: August 24, 2020, School starts in Croatia on September 7, the Education Ministry said on Monday that the main rule is to keep one's distance, not to mix pupils from different classes and to step up hygiene, while face masks will be mandatory only for pupils in higher grades if there is not enough space for them to keep their distance. Pupils should come into contact with a few teachers as possible during one day or period. If there are no other possibilities, it is suggested that the school operates in shifts. For instance, half of the classes could attend school for one week, and the second half next week. In the event of a child exhibiting symptoms, he or she is separated from others and parents come to pick up their child, but there is no need to panic, and an epidemiologist should only be contacted if several children start showing symptoms. If a child tests positive for COVID-19, the entire class or kindergarten group will undergo self-isolation. classes in lower grades of primary school would follow the bubble model so pupils will not leave the classroom, they will have controlled access to the toilet, their teacher will be with them all the time and they will not mix with children from other classes. They will not have to wear face masks, nor will their teacher. Pupils in higher grades of primary schools will only have to wear masks if there is not enough space for them to maintain physical distance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises),Negative COVID-19 Test
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 29, 2020, Science and Education Minister Radovan Fuchs said that closing schools and online classes would be the government's last resort and that he was not considering that measure for now. The school year starts in September, with schools being able to choose the mode of instruction (between physical, mixed and distance learning). Over 92% of schools chose the first mode, i.e. in-classroom, presence-based education. Also, kindergartens are closed because of stuff and positive Covid-19 results.

description: 13 January 2021, the Ministry of Education, the government of Croatia announced that following a prolonged winter break, the second school semester starts on 18 January, with new measures being introduced. Students in grades one to four of elementary school and the final grade of high school resumed physical learning, while all other students follow a distance learning mode. The beginning of the second semester in some schools in areas affected by the earthquake is further postponed.

description: Since October 1, 2021, in Croatia, every student who is absent from classes due to illness, even with primary suspicion of covid-19 (with suspicion of a cold and an ordinary virus, suspicion of allergies, gastrointestinal disorders, ear infection or ear pain, sinusitis, stomach pain, sore throat, headache pain, fatigue, drowsiness, malaise, only a slight increase in body temperature, etc. ) must be tested and can be returned to school after receiving a negative test result or after recovering from covid-19, that is, no earlier than 10 days after the onset of the disease.

description: From March 17, 2022 in Croatia, when due to illness or in any other way it is established that one of the students has a positive result for SARS-COV-2, the school will distribute additional self-test tests to students who are in close contact with a positive student. (usually in the same class section). On the first day after receiving a positive result, it is necessary to conduct a self-test. Students who have a negative test result continue to attend classes, while students who have a positive self-test result stay at home and report this to the doctor and to the school. In case of a positive result of the student's self-examination, the parent/guardian informs the school about this, and the school initiates a self-examination of the class. department, without waiting for confirmation by the RAT test in a medical institution.

description: From March 17, 2022 in Croatia, when due to illness or in any other way it is established that one of the students has a positive result for SARS-COV-2, the school will distribute additional self-test tests to students who are in close contact with a positive student. (usually in the same class section). On the first day after receiving a positive result, it is necessary to conduct a self-test. Students who have a negative test result continue to attend classes, while students who have a positive self-test result stay at home and report this to the doctor and to the school. In case of a positive result of the student's self-examination, the parent/guardian informs the school about this, and the school initiates a self-examination of the class. department, without waiting for confirmation by the RAT test in a medical institution.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with no conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As announced by the Croatian government back on December 23rd, 2020, the national vaccination program against Covid 19 began on December 27th, 2020 with the vaccine Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca, J&J, and  Moderna. The government was set to vaccinate most of its citizens by mid-2021, the health minister Beros said, furthermore the vaccine will be free of charge and given on a voluntary basis.     The vaccination plan is set in three phases and the Priority groups identified are:  *Healthcare professionals who are vaccinated in the first phase mean everyone in the healthcare system who comes into direct contact with patients, including pharmacists and non-healthcare professionals in healthcare facilities. And Vaccination of users and employees of homes for the elderly (and other institutions in the social welfare system) is planned in the Homes,    *2nd phase -Vaccination of persons over 65 years of age and patients with chronic diseases     *In the third phase, when vaccination will be offered to all interested parties,
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Regulatory approval process for administering the COVID-19 vaccine
type_vac_reg: Emergency regulatory approval or authorization granted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Croatia has ordered a million doses of the Moderna vaccine, plus 2.7 million doses of the Oxford vaccine.

description: On January 10, 2021, the Croatian government announced that the received full batch of Moderna vaccine will be sent to the Sisak-Moslavina district next week. The Sisak-Moslavina district received priority for the supply of the vaccine due to the earthquake and the inability to comply with epidemiological measures. This district will receive 4,000 doses of the vaccine with the first priority.

description: On Monday, March 1, 2021, the Ministry of Health announced that all Croatian citizens and residents in Croatia can apply for vaccinations. People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of younger age.

description: On April 3 2021, according to the Croatian Institute of Public Health, Croatia is participating in the European Commission’s joint procurement of the COVID-19 disease vaccine, and the vaccine will be available in Croatia at the same time as in other European Union countries. No change was found.   Vaccinations in accordance with EU, starting with groups A,B: (initially with the Pfizer / BioNtech vaccine). Effective January 26, all airline passengers to the United States ages two years and older must provide a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within three calendar days of travel.

description: On April 19, 2021, the Croatian government announced that vaccines available in Croatia are Pfizer–BioNTech, Moderna, and AstraZeneca. The primary target of the vaccination is the following: 1) employees and residents of homes for the elderly; 2) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases and 3) the rest of the population.    From March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and persons residing in Croatia can apply for vaccination via the cijepise.zdravlje.hr website or by phone at  0800 0011, where applications will be received and recorded in the central registration system. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and date of vaccination to their e-mail address, SMS or phone, depending on the choice at registration. People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of a younger age. Vaccination is carried out in family medicine surgeries, especially for chronic patients, in the  County Institutes of Public Health and at mass vaccination points.    Foreigners who are in Croatia as tourists cannot register for the vaccine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Regulatory approval process for administering the COVID-19 vaccine
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 30, 2021, at the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia announced vaccine consumption. As of August 29, 3,258,375 doses of the vaccine were consumed, and 42.38% of the total population, or 50.91% of the adult population, were vaccinated. As of August 29, 1,289 doses of the vaccine were consumed, of which 823 were vaccinated with the first dose.  As of August 29, 1,719,744 people had been vaccinated with at least one dose, and of them, vaccination was completed for 1,607,430 people (1,538,631 people vaccinated with two doses and 68,799 people vaccinated with Jannsen), accounting for 47.64% of the adult population.

Also, repeated booster vaccination is recommended for people with an increased risk of developing severe forms of covid who were initially vaccinated and revaccinated with the Janssen vaccine. The mRNA vaccine (Comirnaty or Spikevax) is recommended for the second vaccination.

description: On March 3, 2020, Croatia announced the Border Sanitary Inspector or the Sanitary Inspector of the Regional or Central Office of the State Inspectorate will have trucking companies complete questionnaires to confirm truckers are not ill and have not been in contact with someone infected with COVID-19. They will then be under health surveillance as long as the area the driver goes to or from is affected by COVID-19 and they have discussed their travels and health with an epidemiologist. Proof of this discussion with the epidemiologist is required upon returning to Croatia from an affected country to prove to the border patrol officer that the truck driver was already under surveillance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia banned transit through all its border crossings for 30 days, excluding Croatian citizens and foreign nationals returning home, law enforcement, cross-border workers, freight carriers, healthcare professionals, diplomats, civil protection services and teams, staff of international organizations and international military personnel, and passengers in transit. Also excluded are citizens EU and Schengen zone residents as well as those with long-term residence and persons entitled to residence or national long-term visas. These individuals are allowed to return to their home countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia prohibited ships from entering Croatian ports if they have a quarantine requirement. Exceptions to this policy are all ships of Croatian nationality, all ships sailing in the Republic of Croatia for the transport of goods, passenger ships without passengers arriving in the Republic of Croatia for storage, and all ships entering the shipyards for repair. Entering ships and cargo may be subject to health inspection and disinfection, while individuals may face a sanitary health inspection. An extension, effective through May 18, 2020, was announced on April 19, 2020. This policy ended on April 26, 2020, when the cargo line Zadar - Acona was granted an exception to ship prohibition.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 30, 2020, the Croatian Police Directorate has called upon all foreigners on short stay in Croatia who are not able to leave Croatia to send their information to the police in order to be registered. This will help prevent problems at border crossings when leaving the Republic of Croatia.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: registration of foreigners who are unable to leave Croatia
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 31, 2020, the Republic of Croatia temporarily closed six permanent border crossings (Umag, Poreč, Rovinj, Mali Lošinj, Korčula and Ubli) and postponed the opening of eleven seasonal crossings (Umag-ACI Marina, Novigrad, Sali, Božava, Primošten, Komiža, Hvar, Vis, Stari Grad on the island of Hvar, Vela Luka and Cavtat) for international passenger traffic in maritime transport. On June 10, 2020, Croatia stated the reopening of maritime border crossing points and lifted the temporary postponement of seasonal border crossings.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 31, 2020, Croatia Airlines suspended most of their international flights to curb the spread of COVID-19. International flights out of Split and Dubrovnik were suspended. Croatia Airlines stated they would continue operating one flight daily from Zagreb to Frankfurt, largely for repatriation. Flights departing Zagreb for Amsterdam, Brussels, and London were discontinued on April 19, 2020. On May 11, 2020, Croatia Airlines resumed international flights from Split and Dubrovnik. Flights departing from Zagreb to Frankfurt gradually increased while all other flights gradually resumed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

The traffic is suspended at the following border crossings: Svilaj, Gejkovac, Pasin Potok, Bogovolja, Kordunski Ljeskovac, Licka Kaldrma, Bili Brig, Arzano Pazar, Dvorine, Cera, Jovica Most, Sebisina, Slivno, Podprolog, Unka, Vukov Klanac, Imotica, Slano, Hrvatska Dubica and Gabela Polje.

description: On April 7, 2020, Croatia recommended citizens to remain in their place of residence, even if abroad, and to avoid all trips to prevent exposure to COVID-19. They are reminded if they do return to Croatia, restrictions are still in place, including a quarantine.

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatia banned transit through all its border crossings for 30 days, excluding Croatian citizens and foreign nationals returning home, law enforcement, cross-border workers, freight carriers, healthcare professionals, diplomats, civil protection services and teams, staff of international organizations and international military personnel, and passengers in transit. Also excluded are citizens EU and Schengen zone residents as well as those with long-term residence and persons entitled to residence or national long-term visas. These individuals are allowed to return to their home countries. UPDATE: On April 18th, Croatia extended the border closure until May 18, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
As of April 20, 2020, Croatia stated Vehicles in transit through Croatia will use the following border crossing points:
 Croatia – Slovenia border: Bregana and Macelj
 Croatia – Hungary border: Goričan and Duboševica
 Croatia – Bosnia and Herzegovina border: Nova Sela, Stara Gradiška and Slavonski Šamac
 Croatia – Serbia border: Bajakovo
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On April 26, 2020, Croatia announced seaport restrictions are still in place and ships with a quarantine requirement are prohibited from entering Croatia ports, with a single exception. The Zadar - Ancona cargo line may enter Croatian seaports in compliance with the epidemiological measures prescribed by the Croatian Institute of Public Health. On May 18, 2020, all seaport restrictions ended.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 9, 2020, Croatia stated EU citizens and all other nationals may enter Croatia if they have a business reason or other economic interest. They are also allowed to enter Croatia if they have any other reason that cannot be postponed (for example, because they own a property or a boat/yacht, as well as if they attend a funeral). The reason must also be provable, such as the possession of an invitation for a business appointment/meeting, a land register extract, proof of accommodation, marriage certificate, proof of boat/yacht ownership, etc. Travelers must not have visible COVID-19 symptoms to enter.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: On April 7, 2020, Croatia recommended citizens to remain in their place of residence, even if abroad, and to avoid all trips to prevent exposure to COVID-19. They are reminded if they do return to Croatia, restrictions are still in place, including a quarantine. UPDATE: On May 9, 2020, Croatia announced Croatian citizens may enter Croatia freely without restrictions as long as they do not have COVID-19 symptoms.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Starting May 11, 2020, Croatia stated people entering Croatia would no longer be required to self-isolate but would need to follow strict guidelines. They will be required to keep their contacts with other people to the minimum, spend as little time as possible outdoors and maintain hygiene. They are also advised to wear face masks and take their body temperature regularly. If they become symptomatic, Croatian nationals need to report to their GP while foreign nationals should contact the epidemiological service.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On May 16, 2020, Croatia stated when transiting through the Republic of Croatia, drivers in transit are obliged to use motorways. In the case of using a border crossing that is not on the motorway, drivers are obliged to reach the motorway using the shortest route and continue their journey in transit.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On May 9, 2020, Croatia stated EU citizens and all other nationals may enter Croatia if they have a business reason or other economic interest. They are also allowed to enter Croatia if they have any other reason that cannot be postponed (for example, because they own a property or a boat, as well as if they go to a funeral). The reason must also be provable, such as the possession of an invitation for a business appointment/meeting, a land register extract, marriage certificate, etc. Travelers must not have visible COVID-19 symptoms to enter. UPDATE: On May 19, 2020, Croatia extended the existing border restriction to June 15, 2020.

description: On July 1, 2020, the Croatian government temporarily prohibited entry into Croatia. Exempt from these restrictions are citizens of EU/EEA and Schengen member states, the UK, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Switzerland, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, the Vatican, Algeria, Australia, Montenegro, Georgia, Japan, South Korea, Canada, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, China (provided they eliminate restrictions on EU citizens), and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Additionally, health care professionals, cross-branch workers, transport operators, diplomats, those with economic interests (including tourism), and those traveling for schooling or other immediate personal reasons are exempt. Those arriving from exempt countries may enter freely. Travelers are, however, advised to fill out the form on the ENTERCROATIA web-page. All foreign nationals not exempt must provide relevant proof and meet any Croatian government requirements. On July 14, 2020, this measure was extended until July 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Effective December 1, 2020, Croatia announced that third-country nationals (not EU/EEA) may not enter Croatia EXCEPT if they are:
-healthcare workers
-health researchers and caregivers for the elderly
-frontier workers (as well as e.g. athletes as stated in the exceptions for passengers within the EU / EEA)
-workers in the transport sector;
-diplomats
-staff of international organizations and persons invited by international organizations whose physical presence is necessary for the good functioning of those organizations
-military personnel and police officers as well as humanitarian and civil protection personnel in the performance of their duties
-passengers in transit
-persons travelling for schooling purposes
-seafarers (supported by the PCR test result for SARS-CoV-2 not older than 48 hours or by PCR testing for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon arriving to the Republic of Croatia and by self-isolating until they receive a negative test result);
-persons travelling for urgent personal / family reasons, business reasons or other economic interest (supported by the PCR test result for SARS-CoV-2 not older than 48 hours or by PCR testing for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon arriving to the Republic of Croatia and by self-isolating until they receive a negative test result).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Effective December 1, 2020, Croatia announced that third-country nationals (not EU/EEA) may not enter Croatia EXCEPT if they are:
-healthcare workers
-health researchers and caregivers for the elderly
-frontier workers (as well as e.g. athletes as stated in the exceptions for passengers within the EU / EEA)
-workers in the transport sector;
-diplomats
-staff of international organizations and persons invited by international organizations whose physical presence is necessary for the good functioning of those organizations
-military personnel and police officers as well as humanitarian and civil protection personnel in the performance of their duties
-passengers in transit
-persons travelling for schooling purposes
-seafarers (supported by the PCR test result for SARS-CoV-2 not older than 48 hours or by PCR testing for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon arriving to the Republic of Croatia and by self-isolating until they receive a negative test result);
-persons travelling for urgent personal / family reasons, business reasons or other economic interest (supported by the PCR test result for SARS-CoV-2 not older than 48 hours or by PCR testing for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon arriving to the Republic of Croatia and by self-isolating until they receive a negative test result). UPDATE: On January 13, 2021, Croatia announced new exceptions, effective January 14, 2021, that ended this policy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Effective December 1, 2020, Croatia announced passengers coming directly from countries or regions of the EU and Schengen Area that are on the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control's green list may enter without presenting a negative PCR test result for SARS-CoV-2 or self-isolate if they so no signs of illness and have not been in contact with an infected person. If these individuals have travelled through other countries without delay, they are exempt from self-isolate and testing with proof of continuous transit. UPDATE: Effective March 13, 2021, Croatia extended this policy through March 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description: Effective January 14, 2021, Croatia announced passengers, regardless of citizenship, coming from EU/EEA regions that are not on the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control's green list must present a negative PCR test result not older than 48 hours, with limited exceptions. UPDATE: Effective March 13, 2021, Croatia extended this policy through March 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description: Since June 11, 2021, the decision of Croatian Civil Protection Headquarters has allowed entry to the Republic of Croatia for persons arriving from the Schengen area who have been vaccinated with two doses of the vaccine. All travelers arriving from the Schengen area can enter Croatia without quarantine and once they are vaccinated with the second dose, and they do not have to wait 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From June 17, 2021, travelers are not restricted from entering Croatia if they are from a country/regions from the EU/EEA and the Schengen area or if the countries are on the "green list" of the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). For all other countries, entry is allowed if there is a negative PCR test no older than 72 hours or an express test for the SARS-CoV-2 antigen no older than 48 hours. Moderna, Sinopharm or Gamaleya (Sputnik) 22 days ago allowed entry to people with a certificate of vaccination for those who received the first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine from Pfizer, Moderna, Sinopharm or Gamaleya (Sputnik). Entry is allowed to people who have recovered and had a positive test no earlier than 180 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From June 17, 2021, travelers from EU/EEA states/regions who enter Croatia for family or business reasons, including journalists in the performance of their official duties, diplomats, employees of international organizations, medical workers, sailors and transport sector workers are not required to present a negative result of PCR or antigen test for SARS-CoV-2. They need to present an invitation to a business meeting/confirmation of the meeting (issued by a Croatian company or subsidiary, if applicable).

description: Since June 17, 2021, travelers from third countries who are not family members of citizens of the member States of the Schengen Agreement and associated countries of the Schengen Agreement, do not have a long-term residence permit or have a national long-term visa, are subject to a general entry ban. They can enter the Republic of Croatia only in case of an urgent trip: medical personnel, diplomats, transport personnel who must have a certificate of vaccination, a certificate of recovery from the virus or a negative result of a PCR test no older than 72 hours or a negative test no older than 48 hours of antigen tests.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From June 17, 2021, truck drivers, machinists and accompanying railway workers (from the EU and the Schengen area, as well as third countries) do not need a negative test for COVID-19 when entering Croatia. description: From July 1, 2021 to August 15, 2021, to enter Croatia, travelers from Zanzibar (Tanzania), South Africa, Brazil must present a negative PCR test at the Croatian border no older than 72 hours, since these countries are considered a dangerous mutation zone. After entering the country, they must self-isolate for 14 days at their own expense, from which they can leave no earlier than 7 days later using a PCR test at their own expense. This applies regardless of whether travelers are vaccinated or recovered.

description: From July 1, 2021 in Croatia, some people from different categories are exempt from having a valid EU digital certificate of COVID in order to enter the country. If they provide reliable documents, they can also be exempted from passing tests and mandatory self-isolation. This category of people includes medical workers, border guards, transport sector workers, diplomats, employees of international organizations and persons invited by international organizations, military and police personnel, humanitarian and civil defense personnel, transit passengers, passengers traveling for personal/family or business reasons or for any other economic reasons and not being in Croatia or outside of it for more than 12 hours.

description: From July 1, 2021, during border control at the entrance in Croatia, children under the age of twelve traveling accompanied by a parent/guardian are exempt from the obligation to present a negative test result and self-isolate if the parents/guardians have: a valid EU digital certificate for COVID or a negative result of PCR or express antigen - RAT test or if they have a certificate of vaccination against COVID-19 or proof that they have recovered from COVID-19. Children will not have to self-isolate or present negative test results.

description: From July 1, 2021 in Croatia, persons with a negative result of a PCR test or an express antigen test made in the Republic of Croatia due to a short trip to our neighboring or other country and who return to the Republic of Croatia within less than 48 or 72 hours from the date of testing are allowed not to take additional new tests. That is, these travelers will not have to submit a new PCR (valid for 72 hours) or the result of an express antigen test (valid for 48 hours) from the country where they have been for a short time, and they will be allowed entry upon presentation of a test made in the Republic of Croatia.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Since July 1, 2021, in Croatia, persons traveling to the regions of Sisak-Moslavina, Karlovac and Zagreb, for humanitarian reasons related to providing assistance in areas affected by the earthquake, regardless of their citizenship and the area from which they come, are allowed to enter the country on the basis of a preliminary permit from the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia. description: From August 20, 2021, persons traveling for tourist reasons and having a certificate of paid accommodation in a hotel, camping, private housing or a rented ship or other type of tourist accommodation, or who are owners of real estate or boats in the Republic of Croatia, are allowed to enter Croatia. When entering Croatia at the border, they need to show a certificate with a negative result of a PCR test no older than 72 hours or a negative test no older than 48 hours of antigen tests, or a certificate of vaccinations, or confirmation that you have recovered from COVID-19.

description: Since December 15, 2021, in Croatia, in exceptional cases, citizens of the Republic of Croatia and their family members who are long-term residents, who have the right to reside in accordance with other EU directives or national legislation in the Republic of Croatia or who have long-term national visas for the Republic of Croatia are allowed to enter the country even if they came from dangerous zones. description: Since February 15, 2023, the EFGS (European Federation Gateway Service) system for cross-border data exchange between national mobile contact tracking applications has been decommissioned. description: On 23 June 2020, an Announcement from HZJZ regarding the stay of Prime Minister Andrej Plenković in Zadar was published with detailed information on what is permitted and accepted. the CNIPH published the official definition of close contact as a person who has been in face-to-face contact with a person infected with COVID-19 at a distance of fewer than two meters for more than 15 minutes; physical contact such as a hug, kiss, handshake or more intimate contact; a person who has been indoors with a person infected with COVID-19  e.g. household, classroom, meeting room, hospital waiting room, etc. for more than 15 minutes; unprotected contact with the bodily secretions of an infected person; caring for an infected person or handling the biological material of an infectious patient without the use of protective equipment; travel in the same means of transport with an infected person depending on the type of means of transport and distance. Any other type of contact is considered a low risk of infection, and persons making such contact are not subject to epidemiological self-isolation and testing measures
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: A person’s absolute (e.g. GPS) location over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since August 6, 2021, in Croatia, the organizers of all public events must collect written evidence from the participants so that if one of the participants is infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus, the spread of the disease can be more effectively prevented. The following data must be entered in it: first name, last name, phone number and signature of the participant. This evidence must be sent to the civil protection service responsible for the territory and stored for 14 days after the event.

description: On April 4, 2020, the Croatian Psychological Chamber, in cooperation with the Croatian Psychological Society and the County Psychological Societies, activated a Network of Psychological Assistance Telephone Lines, comprising 25 telephone lines, with 150 volunteer psychologists and clinical psychologists on call 24 hours a day. In Zagreb, a psychologist can talk to five telephone lines, and in each county there is one telephone number where citizens can get professional help and advice on how to deal with self-isolation, with life changes that have occurred due to or prevented by coronavirus outbreaks.

description: April 2, 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health announced that when a healthcare worker suspects a SARS-CoV-2 infection based on the above criteria, it is important to properly treat the patient clinically and carry out the necessary diagnostic workup. In the case of laboratory confirmation, the doctor who sent the sample for testing or concluded without testing that it is COVID-19 should immediately notify the territorially competent epidemiologist by phone and fill out the form Report of illness-death from an infectious disease immediately, no later than within 24 hours and submit it to the territorially competent epidemiologist. "However, in parts of Croatia where local disease transmission is established, suspicion of COVID-19 is raised on the basis of symptoms of the acute respiratory disease if the disease cannot be interpreted by another aetiology, whether or not the severity of the clinical picture requires hospitalization." (translated by Google Translate)

description:
On July 13 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health answered several questions regarding testing. The Croatian Health Insurance Institute (HZZO) pays for the testing of the coronavirus for all its insured persons, i.e. it pays for virus typing by molecular methods to contracted healthcare institutions of the HZZO.
In addition to testing, the HZZO ensures payment of health services in full for all health care related to infectious diseases for which the implementation of measures to prevent their spread is determined by law.

description: March 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health posted info about testing and who is on priority. Testing is targeted at symptomatic individuals and priority groups outlined here (unclear when this testing policy came into effect) Croatia's Public Health Center also notes that: "Testing for new coronavirus is not routinely performed in close contacts of a person with confirmed COVID-19 who has no signs of disease. The reason for this is that negative test results in such an asymptomatic phase do not rule out infection. Therefore, testing for SARS-CoV-2 is performed only in case of suspected COVID-19, ie when the clinical and epidemiological criteria of the disease are met."

description: On September 14 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior informed travellers to contact them after they got a negative PCR test. In addition, a test can be arranged at the following locations:?COVID-19 Testing Locations in Croatia. After receiving a negative test locally, travellers will need to contact a local epidemiologist to clear them from self-isolation. Travelers whose test is older than 48 hours will be allowed to enter Croatia, but they will be issued a self-isolation order and will have to be tested again locally, at their own expense. Having an expired PCR test upon arrival will allow for a shortened period of time in self-isolation pending a negative result of a local PCR test. Those who do not provide a negative PCR test upon arrival will be ordered to quarantine/self-isolate for at least 7 days prior to taking a local PCR test. Travellers who fail to present a PCR test upon arrival and refuse to take a test locally will be ordered to self-isolate or quarantine for 14 days. A local test cost ranges from $130 to $300 or more, depending upon the location, and the result can be expected between 24-48 hours.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 15 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health published Consolidated revised recommendations on priorities for testing for SARS-CoV-2, dealing with contacts, and ending isolation and quarantine/self-isolation with reference to persons who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated. In order to reduce the spread of infection, all close contacts of the patient are referred to health surveillance in quarantine self-isolation. Close contacts do not need to be tested either at the beginning or during quarantine self-isolation unless they develop symptoms of the disease if capacity allows or there is an epidemiological indication. Close contacts are subject to quarantine self-isolation health surveillance for 10 days from the last close contact with an infected person. Exceptionally, at the beginning of quarantine self-isolation, close contacts of COVID-19 patients should be tested if they have been identified as close contacts three or more days after exposure to the patient and have in the meantime made contact with vulnerable groups eg. working in a hospital or social service provider. accommodation and stay for elderly and seriously ill adults and people with disabilities. Upon completion of quarantine, it is not necessary to test individuals if they do not develop symptoms  unless they are immunocompromised.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19

description:
On January 20 2021, the government of Croatia made updates about health testing.   Effective January 26, all airline passengers to the United States ages two years and older must provide a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within three calendar days of travel. Alternatively, travellers to the U.S. may provide documentation from a licensed health care provider of having recovered from COVID-19 in the 90 days preceding travel.  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Croatia? Yes
If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes

description:
On January 29 2021, the government of Croatia published news on vaccines, including information for travellers too. According to the Croatian Institute of Public Health, Croatia is participating in the European Commission’s joint procurement of the COVID-19 disease vaccine, and the vaccine will be available in Croatia at the same time as in other European Union countries.  The current Vaccination Plan has three phases: 1) employees and residents of homes for the elderly (and other institutions that provide accommodation in the social welfare system) and health professionals, 2) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases, and 3) the rest of the population.  For more information about the Croatian government’s COVID-19 Vaccination Plan, visit the Croatian Institute of Public Health information page. Contact your local healthcare provider for information on how you may qualify for vaccination at this time.
Information from the CDC regarding COVID-19 vaccination.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 7 2021, in accordance with the instructions of the Ministry of Health, the work of separate clinics for the examination of patients suspected of coronavirus infection, the so-called covid-19 ambulances, is temporarily suspended. such a decision is prompted, in addition to the favourable epidemiological situation, by the weak interest of citizens in rapid antigen testing, as well as very high external temperatures at which it is not recommended to perform a rapid test. general/family physicians can perform rapid antigen tests in the office and enter the result of the test in the central covid-19 testing register used as a reference system for issuing EU digital covid certificates.

description: On July 15 2021,  the Croatian Institute of Public Health published updated its recommendation for testing. According to these, priority groups for testing are  a  Symptomatic persons who, due to their characteristics, primarily occupations, have a high potential spreading the disease to vulnerable groups  healthcare professionals and hospitalized patients, with signs and symptoms of acute respiratory infection, wards and employees of homes for the elderly and infirm and other social welfare institutions ; b  Symptomatic persons who, due to their characteristics, have a high potential for infecting a large number of people at risk of rapid spread of infection and cluster formation  prisoners and prison staff, refugees and asylum seekers, homeless people, members of ethnic   cultural groups whose lifestyle is conducive to the transmission of the disease by droplets and direct contact, etc. ; c  Symptomatic persons with increased risk of severe disease and complications  persons aged 65 years and older, persons with chronic diseases  diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, chronic lung diseases, immuno-compromised conditions, chronic kidney disease ; d  If a grouping of respiratory disease that cannot be interpreted by another etiology is observed in a health institution, it is necessary to test symptomatic persons;
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Symptomatic people,Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19

description: Since March 17, 2022, in Croatia, all applicants, employees participating in the state entrance exam, personal assistants and other persons performing duties in the period before the first exam and before the last exam are recommended, as far as possible, to comply with the rules that reduce the possibility of infection (consistent observance of physical distancing from other persons with whom they do not live together, and enhanced personal hygiene, avoiding large gatherings). A dispenser with a disinfectant should be placed at the entrance to the institution so that each visitor can disinfect his hands. Immediately before the arrival of the applicant, it is recommended to ventilate the room (entrance and fresh air circulation for at least half an hour). The venue of the state graduation and the premises adjacent to it, including sanitary facilities, must be thoroughly washed and disinfected before each exam and at the end of each working day as part of the scheduled cleaning.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From July 4, 2022, in Croatia, camps and campsites are recommended to carry out disinfection measures as efficiently as possible around the perimeter. At the entrance to the facility, visitors should be given a dispenser with hand sanitizer and a visual sign instructing on the mandatory disinfection of hands at the entrance. Door handles and handrails, the surfaces of handrails and edges of refrigerator doors, as well as other surfaces that are often touched by customers, should be regularly wiped with an alcohol-based disinfectant or other agent with a declared viricidal effect in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. After the departure of each group of guests, the table, chair and other surfaces touched by the guests should be wiped with a disinfectant, i.e. tablecloths should be removed, even if they have no visible contamination.

description:
On March 22, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23, 2020. 

Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can’t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.

Passes will be required and signed by appropriate entities. UPDATE: On April 18, 2020, the Croatian Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic stated the lockdown will be extended until May 4, 2020, but the government will look at whether it was possible to gradually ease restrictions on movement.

description: From March 21 2021, the government of Croatia decided to take measures such as wearing protective masks mandatory in all closed spaces throughout the country. Masks are also mandatory in open spaces where a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters cannot be maintained. In addition, individuals must maintain at least 2 meters of social distance indoors and at least 1.5 meters outdoors. Also, Private gatherings in homes are limited to 10 people from two households and must end at 22:00. And other kinds of strict measures such as no weddings and limited 25 people funerals are included.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 6 2021, the Croatian Institute of Public Health take measurements in order to reduce the spread of infection, such as all close contacts of the affected person are referred to health surveillance in quarantine/self-isolation. New changes are the exception to the need for testing and quarantine after recovering from an illness or vaccination is extended from three to six months. The British variant of SARS-CoV-2 has been removed from the list of variants for which the duration of the quarantine is 14 days and mandatory testing at the end of the quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On February 24, 2020. the Croatian Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including: 
All travelers coming from the affected areas are foreseen to be placed in self-isolation with health surveillance and are obliged to report daily to the epidemiologist. The affected areas include China, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and the provinces of Lombardy and Veneto in Italy. This policy ended on March 12, 2020.

description:

measures aimed at individuals traveling from any COVID-19 affected countries: 

Albania, Algeria, Andorra, Argentine, Armenia, Australia, Austria, Bahamas, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Belarus, 
Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Brunei, Bulgaria, Cambodia, Cameroon, Canada, Chile, China (except Hubei province), Colombia, Costa Rica, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany (except the County of Heinsberg), Greece, Guam, Guyana, Hong Kong, Hungary, Iceland, India, Indonesia, Iraq, Ireland, Israel, Jamaica, Japan, Kenya, Kuwait, Latvia, Lebanon, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malaysia, Maldives, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Mongolia, Montenegro, Morocco, Netherlands, New Zealand, North Macedonia, Norway, Panama, Paraguay, Pakistan, Peru, Philippines, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Romania, Rwanda, Russia, San Marino, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Serbia, Singapore, Slovakia, Slovenia (except Bela Krajina and Dolenjska regions), South Africa, South Korea (except city of Daegu and the County of Cheongdo), Spain, Sri Lanka, Sweden, Switzerland, Thailand, Tunisia, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States of America, and Vietnam.

description:
On March 12, 2020, Croatia stated any foreign nationals, including U.S. citizens, traveling to Croatia from narrowly defined COVID-19 affected areas are mandated to spend 14 days in official government quarantine facilities. Placement in quarantine is at the expense of the traveler. These areas are:

China: Hubei province
Germany: the County of Heinsberg in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia
Iran
Italy
Slovenia: Bela Krajina and Dolenjska regions
South Korea: the city of Daegu and the County of Cheongdo

description: On March 16, 2020, Croatia announced that anyone disobeying the order to self-isolate or other measures imposed over the coronavirus outbreak faces a fine of HRK 8,000 (€1,060), while repeat offenders face a fine of up to HRK 120,000 (€16,000).

description: On March 9, 2020, Croatia stated truck drivers who drive to coronavirus affected areas must stay in self-isolation upon arrival in Croatia until they leave for the next transport. Upon their return, they are obliged to undergo self-isolation. UPDATE: On March 20, 2020, the Croatian Ministry of Health stated truck drivers will not leave their cabin for unloading goods. After unloading, drivers will quarantine in their homes or isolation organizes by their company. If organized by their company, they may break quarantine to return to work. They may not break quarantine if they are in their own homes or another private location.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 17, Croatian Parliament, pursuant to Article 89 of the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia, enacted decision on the promulgation of the law on amendments to the law on protection of the population from infectious diseases. With new amendments, for the people who are suspected of suffering from COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus or healthy persons who have been in contact with persons suffering from the disease, or come from the area of the affected COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, health professionals may determine the isolation in their own home, or in another suitable space - a self-isolation, if appropriate conditions are met (Art. 8). Furthermore, for each violation of the provisions of this Act, the sanitary inspector of the State Inspectorate may, on the spot, charge a fine in the amount of HRK 5,000.00 (660 euros). (Art. 17).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Mar 26 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared to liberalize the procedure related to Croatian and foreign citizens that drive for Croatian employers in international transport. Following loading or unloading they can be in self-isolation at their homes and no longer have to go into quarantine. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors. UPDATE: As of May 7, 2020, Croatia stated the requirement for international goods drivers to quarantine upon arrival does not apply anymore.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 9, 2020, Croatia stated self-isolation is no longer required for all passengers at border crossings when entering the Republic of Croatia. It can only be assigned to individuals who are found by border control to have been in contact with a person with COVID-19. Individuals instructed to self-isolate prior to May 9th, 2020 must still comply with those instructions. Upon entering the Republic of Croatia, the border police hand over a leaflet with instructions and recommendations of the Croatian Institute of Public Health, which must be followed for the next 14 days. On June 25, 2020, Croatia introduced a mandatory self-isolation for individuals entering Croatia from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia, and Serbia with limited exceptions, ending this policy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Effective May 11, 2020, Croatia announced people entering Croatia are no longer required to self-isolate, but must keep contacts with other people to a minimum, spend as little time as possible outdoors, and maintain hygiene. They are advised to wear face masks and take their body temperature regularly. If symptoms arise, Croatian nationals must report to their GP while foreign nationals should contact the epidemiological service.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 25, 2020, Croatian Civil Protection Headquarters introduced mandatory self-isolation for people entering Croatia from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia and Serbia. There are exceptions for those who, due to the nature of their work and living circumstances, will not have to isolate themselves, and among them are cross-border workers and those transiting through these four countries and through Croatia. Additionally, those crossing for a funeral, medical care, or transport will not be subjected to this rule.

description: Beginning July 1, 2020, Croatia ended the self-isolation measures for passengers arriving to the nation. On July 10, 2020, this policy ended when Croatia announced a mandatory quarantine for those arriving without a PCR test or with an expired test (older than 48 hours).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Beginning July 11, 2020, Croatia announced a mandatory 14-day quarantine for those arriving to Croatia without a PCR test. They will have the option of quarantining for at least 7 days prior to taking a local PCR test. Upon receiving a negative test, they must contact a local epidemiologist to clear them from self-isolation. Those who refuse to take a test locally will be ordered to self-isolate or quarantine for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: Beginning July 11, 2020, Croatia announced those arriving with an expired PCR test must quarantine and must be tested again locally at their own expense. An expired PCR test will allow for a shortened period of self-isolation (7 days), pending a negative result of a local PCR test.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: Beginning July 11, 2020, Croatia announced those arriving with an expired PCR test must quarantine and must be tested again locally at their own expense. An expired PCR test will allow for a shortened period of self-isolation, pending a negative result of a local PCR test. UPDATE: On August 31, 2020, Croatia extended this measure through September 15, 2020.

description: Beginning July 11, 2020, Croatia announced a mandatory 14-day quarantine for those arriving to Croatia without a PCR test. They will have the option of quarantining for at least 7 days prior to taking a local PCR test. Upon receiving a negative test, they must contact a local epidemiologist to clear them from self-isolation. Those who refuse to take a test locally will be ordered to self-isolate or quarantine for 14 days. UPDATE: On August 31, 2020, Croatia extended this measure through September 15, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: Beginning July 11, 2020, Croatia announced those arriving with an expired PCR test must quarantine and must be tested again locally at their own expense. description: Effective December 1, 2020,  Croatia announced passengers, regardless of citizenship, coming from EU/EEA regions that are NOT on the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control's green list who present with either an expired test or without a test must have a PCR tests for SARS-CoV-2 done immediately upon arrival in Croatia. Passengers will remain in self-isolation until they receive a negative test result.

description: On January 13, 2021, Croatia announced the Croatian Public Health Institute (HZJZ) has a list of countries with special epidemiological measures. Travelers from countries on this list must show a negative PCR test not older than 48 hours when entering Croatia and they will be issued a 14-day isolation order. The mandatory quarantine period could be decreased to seven days if travelers undergo PCR testing in authorized institutions and they test negative. The countries currently on this list include Great Britain and South Africa.

description: From June 17, 2021, if travelers do not have a negative PCR test or the necessary vaccination certificate, travelers can free themselves from self-isolation with the help of PCR or an antigen test conducted in Croatia (at their own expense). If it is impossible to conduct the test , the person is obliged to use self - isolation for a period of 10 days .
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From June 17, 2021, travelers who have visited the mutation zones in the last 14 days before entering Croatia (currently South Africa, Brazil, Tanzania and India) after entering the country must self-isolate for 14 days (at their own expense), from which they can exit only after 7 days using PCR-test (at your own expense) in case of a negative result.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since July 1, 2021, the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia has decided that an epidemiological measure of self-isolation is required automatically for all transit passengers. All travelers, including transport sector personnel, must self-isolate for a period of 10 days within 12 hours from the moment of entry into the Republic of Croatia if they do not leave Croatia.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From July 1, 2021 in Croatia during border control at entry, if a passenger has expired: PCR test within 72 hours from the moment of taking a sample or he/she has no PCR test result at all, or if the validity period of the rapid antigen test for SARS-CoVid of 48 hours from the moment the sampling has expired or they do not have it at all and they meet other entry conditions, they may be allowed to enter the Republic of Croatia.They will be required to immediately take a PCR or RAT test in the Republic of Croatia at their own expense, with the obligation of self-isolation until a negative test result is obtained. If a person cannot pass one of the above tests, the total duration of self-isolation is 10 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 1, 2021, in Croatia, the removal of self-isolation measures assigned at the border checkpoint is possible if travelers receive a negative result of PCR or an express antigen test, but not serological tests. After receiving negative results, travelers will need to send the results to the specified e-mail address of the border crossing point where the passenger is assigned a self-isolation measure. One of the previously mentioned tests must be obtained by the healthcare institution in which the check was carried out so that the results are taken and self-isolation measures are lifted.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 26, 2021, in Croatia, travelers from countries that require quarantine can shorten the period of quarantine and self-isolation by receiving a negative result after a PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 in an authorized institution.The test can be taken only after the seventh day of self-isolation at the expense of the traveler. The documentation of recovery and vaccination does not exempt from providing a negative PCR test and quarantine for travelers arriving from these countries.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since April 13, 2022, there is no quarantine in Croatia after contact with a positive person. People who are currently in quarantine can cancel the quarantine in consultation with a doctor. Regardless of the status of vaccination and recovery, individuals do not remain in quarantine, but follow the following instructions: wear a mask for 10 days after the last contact and conduct self-testing on the 5th day, as well as avoid mass gatherings of people and contacts with people with an increased risk of developing more severe forms of COVID-19 disease. Despite the fact that the introduction of a sanitary supervision measure and quarantine are not mandatory, there are situations in which close contacts who wish to do this can still receive a doctor's order to introduce a medical supervision measure in quarantine/self-isolation for up to 7 days from the last contact with a positive person. In consultation with a doctor, the introduction of self-isolation may be justified for people with an increased risk of severe forms of COVID-19 disease.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Mar 14 Istria County his shuttering all hospitality businesses for the next month in a move to try and curb the spread of the coronavirus. All cafes and restaurants will be closed until April 14. Food delivery services and soup kitchens are exempt but are under strict cautionary measures, said Damir Kozlovac, the head of county civil defense services.

description:
On March 21, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has adopted a new set of measures, according to which taxi service providers' employers are obliged to inform and educate employees about the disease itself and recommendations/ general and specific protection measures.

Employers are obliged to ensure working conditions that include sufficient amounts of soap and disposable towels in the sanitary facilities, regular cleaning of the premises with disinfectants, and to organize the normal functioning of business processes in the company's premises (with larger taxi carriers and in call centres).

Taxi service providers are also obliged to have the measures prescribed by this Decision displayed in a visible place in their vehicles that they provide services.

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has activated a new set of measures, according to which stores and establishments which are allowed to continue to operate in accordance with the restrictions are obliged to sell all bulk goods packaged, ensure that there are no crowds when entering shops and facilities, and organize work in such a way as to ensure the greatest possible distance between workers while respecting strict measures of social distance. UPDATE: On 19 March, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has adopted a new decision on measures to restrict social gatherings, work in shops, service activities and the holding of sports and cultural events, except for some stores and establishments. On 18 April, this Decision has been extended until 4 May, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has activated a new set of measures, according to which employers are required to organize work from home where possible, cancel meetings or organize teleconferences and use other technologies to hold remote meetings, cancel business trips outside the country except as necessary and prohibit entry into workplaces of workers who have fever and respiratory distress, especially dry cough and shortness of breath UPDATE: On 19 March, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has adopted a new decision on measures to restrict social gatherings, work in shops, service activities and the holding of sports and cultural events, except for some stores and establishments. On 18 April, this Decision has been extended until 4 May, 2020.

description: On April 24, 2020, Croatia announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Maximum number of employees
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 24, 2020, Croatian government announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection.

description:
On March 19 the Croatian government ordered the suspension of all businesses for 30 days with the exception of grocery stores, food and hygiene items, market and fish markets, specialized stores selling and dispensing (pharmacies), specialized stores selling and dispensing veterinary medicinal products, agricultural pharmacies, gas stations, kiosks, bakery, chemical laundry, specialized stores selling orthopedic and other aids, specialized baby equipment stores, specialized animal feed stores, issuance of construction materials based on retail order
logistic and distribution centers for food, beverages and hygiene products and wholesalers. UPDATE: On April 27, the Croatian government permitted shops to open, except those operating within big shopping centers and those in the service sector with close contact.

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has activated a new set of measures, according to which stores and establishments which are allowed to continue to operate in accordance with the restrictions are obliged to sell all bulk goods packaged, ensure that there are no crowds when entering shops and facilities, and organize work in such a way as to ensure the greatest possible distance between workers while respecting strict measures of social distance. UPDATE: On May 10, 2020, it was announced that of Monday, May 11, 2020, the decision of the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia on the necessary measures to limit social gatherings, work in shops, service activities and the holding of sports and cultural events will change and the sectors will reopen.

Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. description: On April 24, 2020, Croatia announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection. UPDATE: On May 10, 2020, the Croatian government has announced that all training grounds and gyms can work from May 13, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Maximum number of employees

description: On June 7, 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on amending the Decision on working hours and the way of operation of trade activities for the duration of the declared epidemic of the disease COVID-19, which abolished the mandatory one-hour break between two shifts for the purpose of changing workers and cleaning and disinfecting the premises for stores that work twice. The Headquarters still recommends that cleaning and disinfection of store premises be carried out regularly in accordance with the recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute of Public Health.

description: On August 10, 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health announced that multiplexes in shopping malls can reopen, five months after closing. At the entrance to the cinema area and in the interior, there should be means for hand disinfection and a notice that hand disinfection is mandatory. When it comes to cinema staff, they must measure their temperature every day before coming to work, and if it is higher than 37.2 degrees, they must not come to work. It is also recommended that visitors take their temperature before coming to the cinema. HZJZ points out that film screening is possible only in halls that can meet conditions such as maintaining physical distance. Also, the number of people who can be in the hall at the same time must be limited, and this number is determined by the organizer according to the size of the space and the type of event. A distance of at least 1.5 meters between visitors is recommended between each seat, as well as when entering, moving and exiting. The exit of visitors should be organized so that they exit one by one, and those closest to the door exit first. Organizers must keep records of visitors, and online ticket sales are encouraged to avoid physical contact.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Maximum number of employees,Temperature Check,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)

description: On Sunday, October 25, 2020, Croatia’s COVID-19 crisis management team presented a new set of restrictions that start from Monday the 26th: particular protocols are specified for plays and cultural programmes, film screenings in cinemas, religious rites, exhibitions in museums and similar events. Workers with a high body temperature and problems in their respiratory systems are required not to go to work. Also working from home, if possible, is recommended. The authorities have banned the sale of alcohol from midnight to 6 AM. The measures are set to last 14 days.

description: On November 11, 2020, the National Civil Protection Headquarters, at the proposal of the Civil Protection Headquarters of Sibenik-Knin County, amended the Decision on introducing necessary epidemiological measures for Sibenik-Knin County, which enters into force tomorrow, November 12. The working hours of all types of catering facilities are limited until 10 PM. It is recommended that employers organize work with the greatest possible distance between workers and maintain a minimum physical distance of at least 2 meters, whenever possible.
