description: In view of new instructions by the Croatian Institute for Public Health, since November 22, 2020, employers are required to: prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath; reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible; introduce work from home, when possible given the nature of the work; introduce sliding working hours, where possible; organize work in shifts, i.e. groups, where possible; reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum; regularly ventilate the areas where workers reside.

description: On November 22, 2020, Croatian government introduced new country-wide measures, including the obligation for all shops, stores, and catering facilities to clearly display at the entrance the notice of the largest possible number of customers who can be in the store at the same time in accordance with the recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute of Public Health and strict adherence to the permitted number of customers; obligation for all stores, shops and shopping centers to take additional measures during the expected arrival of a large number of customers (discounts, rebates, pre-holiday purchases, etc.) so that more customers do not stay in their premises at the same time and to ensure compliance epidemiological measures; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM.

description: On November 22, 2020, Croatian government introduced new country-wide measures, including the obligation for all shops, stores, and catering facilities to clearly display at the entrance the notice of the largest possible number of customers who can be in the store at the same time in accordance with the recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute of Public Health and strict adherence to the permitted number of customers; obligation for all stores, shops and shopping centers to take additional measures during the expected arrival of a large number of customers (discounts, rebates, pre-holiday purchases, etc.) so that more customers do not stay in their premises at the same time and to ensure compliance epidemiological measures; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM. UPDATE: Croatian officials announced new COVID-19 measures to help mitigate the spread of the virus. As of 12:00 AM on November 28, the following measures will apply until December 21. Restaurants and cafes will be closed. All amateur plays, concerts, programs, practice, workshops, and dance schools are closed. Catering facilities in hotels and camps are permitted to serve their guests. Food delivery and drive-thrus are permitted, and bakeries may remain open until 10:00 pm. Gyms, fitness, recreation centers are closed. Foreign language schools may only operate online. Alcohol will not be sold from 10:00pm to 6:00am. It is now mandatory to wear a face covering in the following situations: shoppers/customers in stores; clients where face to face contact is required; all services that require close contact (hairdressers, salons, etc.); customers in all hospitality services who serve and prepare beverages and food, except while sitting in their seats and consuming food, drinks or beverages.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Since 12 December, 2020, new restrictions for shops and shopping centres will be implemented, as announced by the Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic. Shops and shopping centres will have to ensure 10 to 20 square metres of space per customer, depending on the size of the net sales area. Under the new decision, shops with a net sales area of less than 10 square metres will be able to admit only one customer at a time. Shops that have a net sales area of 11 to 100 square metres will have to ensure at least 10 square metres of space per customer. Shops with a net sales area of 101 to 200 square metres will have to provide at least 12 square metres of space per customer, those with a net sales area of 201 to 2,000 square metres will have to provide at least 16 square metres, and all shops with a net sales area of more than 2,000 square metres will have to ensure at least 20 square metres of space per customer. In shopping centres, the maximum number of customers will be determined by ensuring at least 16 square metres of space per customer, and all shops and shopping centres will be required to display a notice with the maximum number of customers that can be inside at the same time at the entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of number of customers,Size of store limited (e.g. stores smaller than 800 sq meters)

description:
On November 20, 2020, the Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection published a decision on temporary regulation of work and limitation of working hours of catering facilities and other providers of catering services. Catering facilities can only operate from 6 AM to 10 PM nationwide starting from November 22.The stated working hours also apply to providers of catering services in the household and family farms, except for accommodation services. The stated working hours do not refer to catering facilities from the groups Hotels, Camps and Other catering facilities for accommodation, except for catering facilities of other groups that work in their composition. UPDATE: On December 21, 2020, The Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia suspended the operation of catering establishments and the provision of catering services on family farms, except for catering establishments from the groups "Hotels", "Camps" and the types of Učenički or Studentski dom or Akademis from the group "Other catering establishments for accommodation", which may only serve guests who use the accommodation service in them, i.e. pupils or students. As an exception to this anti-epidemic measure, catering facilities from the "Restaurants" group, "Catering facilities" group and types of cafes, pubs, buffets, taverns, taverns and cellars from the "Bars" group are allowed to prepare and deliver food and drinks. The aforementioned catering establishments can deliver food in compliance with all anti-epidemic measures in one of the following ways:
    -by personal pick-up at the entrance to the catering facility without entering the same
    -delivery of food from the restaurant with its own delivery vehicle
    -delivery of food from a catering facility based on a business cooperation agreement concluded between the caterer and a third party (legal or natural-artisan), who are registered and entered in the Register of Food Business Entities
    -by the so-called "drive in" method.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On December 21, 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures, according to which there will be limitation of opening hours for bakeries and bread and bakery shops up until 10 PM; prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages from 10 PM to 6 AM; suspension of gyms, fitness centers and sports and recreation centers. The measures also include the suspension of children's and other workshops and organized dance schools; foreign language schools can only perform their activities online or in another way to maintain contact at a distance. Driving schools can hold the theoretical part only online or in another way to maintain contacts at a distance: driving lessons can last a maximum of 45 minutes with mandatory body temperature measurement before entering the car, a break between two candidates must be a minimum of 10 minutes for airing and disinfecting the car, and records of all participants in driving lessons must be kept. The measures are set to last until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Temperature Check

description: On December 21, 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures, according to which there will be limitation of opening hours for bakeries and bread and bakery shops up until 10 PM; prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages from 10 PM to 6 AM; suspension of gyms, fitness centers and sports and recreation centers. The measures also include the suspension of children's and other workshops and organized dance schools; foreign language schools can only perform their activities online or in another way to maintain contact at a distance. Driving schools can hold the theoretical part only online or in another way to maintain contacts at a distance: driving lessons can last a maximum of 45 minutes with mandatory body temperature measurement before entering the car, a break between two candidates must be a minimum of 10 minutes for airing and disinfecting the car, and records of all participants in driving lessons must be kept. The measures are set to last until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Contact tracing measures
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In view of new instructions by the Croatian Institute for Public Health, since November 22, 2020, employers are required to: prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath; reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible; introduce work from home, when possible given the nature of the work; introduce sliding working hours, where possible; organize work in shifts, i.e. groups, where possible; reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum; regularly ventilate the areas where workers reside. UPDATE: The necessary epidemiological measures were extended on December 21, 2020, by the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of working hours for employees (e.g. work at home policies),Maximum size of business meetings,Maximum number of employees,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: As announced by the Croatian government, starting February 15, 2021, bars and restaurants will be allowed to open for outdoor service, and gyms and fitness centres will be permitted to operate but must comply with the epidemiological measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Fitness centres and gyms need to provide at least 20 square metres per person at one time and the premises must be ventilated and equipment needs to be sanitised between users. Dressing rooms and showers must not be used. Casinos and other gambling venues will also be allowed to work until 10 PM; the number of visitors needs to be restricted to ensure at least 7 square metres per person. Hospitality sections of casinos and gaming rooms are to remain shut. Cafes will be permitted to sell drinks to go. All caterers can provide deliveries of food, drinks, beverages and sweets to go. People receiving food and beverages from hospitality establishments must not linger on terraces or in front of the provider’s premises or enter inside. People waiting for deliveries need to keep their distance and wear a mask. The containment measures will be revised on March 1, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Delivery and Takeaway Only
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On March 31, 2021 the headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia announced restricting the operation of catering establishments and family farms that provide catering services. Food, drinks, beverages and desserts can only be served on open terraces or other open areas for serving, with strict adherence to prescribed epidemiological measures and special recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute for Public healthcare. Working hours can be set from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. The measures enter into force from April 1st, 2021 until the 15th April, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting 1 April, 2021, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia have adopted new epidemiological measures. These include: limitation of working hours for bakeries and shops for bread and bakery products until 10 PM; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM; restricting the operation of catering facilities and family farms that provide catering services in such a way that food, drinks, beverages and sweets can be served only on open terraces or other open service areas, with strict adherence to instructions of the Croatian Institute for Public health, and working hours from 6 AM to 10 PM. Hospitality establishments can deliver food, drinks, beverages and desserts in compliance with all anti-epidemic measures in one of the following ways:
            by personal pick-up at the entrance to the catering facility without entering the same
            by delivery from the restaurant with its own delivery vehicle
            delivery from a catering establishment based on a business cooperation agreement concluded between the caterer and a third party (legal or natural-artisans), who are registered and entered in the Register of Entities in the Food Business
            by the so-called "drive in" method.

The working hours of casinos, club vending machines and payment points for betting may be determined from 8 AM to 10 PM, with a ban on the provision of catering services on their premises. The measures will last till June 30, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 1, 2021, Croatia restricted the operation of catering facilities and family farms that provide catering services so that food, beverages, and sweets can be served in the outdoor service area, and only to guests sitting at tables. description:
Starting 1 April, 2021, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia have adopted new epidemiological measures. These include: limitation of working hours for bakeries and shops for bread and bakery products until 10 PM; ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 10 PM and 6 AM; restricting the operation of catering facilities and family farms that provide catering services in such a way that food, drinks, beverages and sweets can be served only on open terraces or other open service areas, with strict adherence to instructions of the Croatian Institute for Public health, and working hours from 6 AM to 10 PM. Hospitality establishments can deliver food, drinks, beverages and desserts in compliance with all anti-epidemic measures in one of the following ways:
            by personal pick-up at the entrance to the catering facility without entering the same
            by delivery from the restaurant with its own delivery vehicle
            delivery from a catering establishment based on a business cooperation agreement concluded between the caterer and a third party (legal or natural-artisans), who are registered and entered in the Register of Entities in the Food Business
            by the so-called "drive in" method.

The working hours of casinos, club vending machines and payment points for betting may be determined from 8 AM to 10 PM, with a ban on the provision of catering services on their premises. The measures will last till June 30, 2021. UPDATE: As of 2 July 2021, restaurants can offer food and beverages for takeout/delivery and may also serve guests seated both indoors and in an open-air space. Coffee shops and bars can only serve guests in open-air spaces. Nightclubs are closed. Casinos and betting shops are now open from 8 AM until 11 PM. Alcohol will not be sold from 11 PM to 6 AM.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures: curfew at midnight for all objects, including grocery stores and bakeries. In addition to delivery, drive-in or take-away, restaurants, catering facilities, cafés and bars may also serve guests outside (from 6 AM to 12 AM) and indoors. The number of guests in catering establishments should be limited so that a minimum distance of 1.5 m between guests can be ensured; disinfectants should be made available for the guests. Betting shops, casinos and slot machine clubs are allowed to work from 8 AM to 12 AM, but without serving food/drinks. No alcoholic beverages may be sold between 12 AM and 6 AM. The retail shops are open from 8 AM to 9 PM (until 11 PM at the latest). Masks are compulsory for all employees and customers; all shops must provide disinfectants to customers. Shops are obliged to indicate the maximum number of people allowed at the entrance (based on at least 10m²/person). Hairdressers, massage parlors, locksmiths, etc. are allowed to work in compliance with masks, disinfectants, disinfection of the premises, transparent barriers, etc. The same measures apply to hotels; they should ensure physical distancing of at least 1.5m among guests. Conditions for fitness centres: 20 m² per person, disinfection of the equipment after each use, customers must bring their own towels and mats, showers remain closed, distance rules must be strictly observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

Betting shops, casinos and slot machine clubs are allowed to work from 8 AM to 12 AM, but without serving food/drinks. No alcoholic beverages may be sold between 12 AM and 6 AM. The retail shops are open from 8 AM to 9 PM (until 11 PM at the latest). Masks are compulsory for all employees and customers; all shops must provide disinfectants to customers. Shops are obliged to indicate the maximum number of people allowed at the entrance (based on at least 10m²/person). Hairdressers, massage parlors, locksmiths, etc. are allowed to work in compliance with masks, disinfectants, disinfection of the premises, transparent barriers, etc. The same measures apply to hotels; they should ensure physical distancing of at least 1.5m among guests. Conditions for fitness centres: 20 m² per person, disinfection of the equipment after each use, customers must bring their own towels and mats, showers remain closed, distance rules must be strictly observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description:
As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures.
    Employers must prohibit all employees with a high body temperature, breathing difficulties, especially dry cough and shortness of breath, from coming to work; introducing home office, flexitime or work in shifts or groups and to reduce the number of physical meetings whenever possible; post important safety regulations, hygiene and health instructions in the offices; ensure sufficient protective equipment such as gloves, masks, protective suits, helmets, etc. Installation of physical barriers (plexiglass and similar barriers to reduce employee contact with customers); ensuring a place for disinfecting hands; ensuring through better distribution of space and working hours that the minimum distance between employees is guaranteed; meetings only with fewer than 5 people (if possible meeting online, by email or by phone); during breaks, making sure employees do not sit together in groups. Disinfection and cleaning of the work premises (all contact surfaces at least twice a day); regular airing of the rooms, special protection for employees with chronic illnesses and cancer (work from home office), etc. 

Additional regulations for construction: limit all indoor construction meetings to a minimum; divide construction workers into several groups that physically separate the groups; the tasks of building supervision also form groups; draw up evacuation plans; move unneeded people to home office.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Construction") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Since July 4, 2022, travel agencies in Croatia have been recommended to reduce the number of clients. description: Effective March 22, 2020, the Croatian national civil protection authority decided to suspend all public transportation services, including transport by tram, for the next 30 days. This measure includes:  public passenger transport by road within the country (except for taxi services), international public passenger transport by road, passenger transport by rail, tram and other city public transportation, as well as all other types of public transportation (such as funicular railway). This policy ended on May 11, 2020, when the government allowed intercity road, rail transport, and other forms of public transportation to resume in accordance with the regulations announced April 27, 2020.

description: On 22 December, 2020, according to the measures taken by the national government, the Croatian national postal service HP suspended deliveries to the United Kingdom until further notice following the discovery of a new, more contagious strain of the coronavirus in that country. UPDATE: The Croatian Post (HP) stated on Tuesday, 12 January, 2021 that the postal traffic between Croatia and the United Kingdom had resumed after its suspension on 22 December, 2020. Twenty days ago, the Croatian national postal service HP suspended deliveries to the United Kingdom until further notice following the discovery of a new, more contagious strain of the coronavirus in that country. HP said today that the deliveries had been resumed on 11 January. HP also underscores that since 1 January 2021, the United Kingdom has been treated as a third country, that is a country outside the European Union, and this impacts the customs treatment of deliveries to and from that country.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Those who refuse to present a certificate cannot enter the premises.

description: On May 10, 2020, Croatia announced mass gathering restrictions for zoos. Only 15 visitors per 100 m² inside the zoo will be allowed at once. The maximum number of visitors that can stay in the zoo at the same time in the indoor area is the net area in square meters divided by 7, which is 15 visitors per 100 m² of net area. If it is difficult to determine the net area, the maximum number of visitors who may be in the zoo at the same time can be calculated by dividing the gross area by 15. After the maximum number of visitors has entered, further entries are only possible when one of the visitors leaves. i.e. to one who goes out, one can enter. Limiting ticket sales is to the largest number of visitors who can be in the zoo at the same time is recommended.

description: Effective May 29, 2020, Croatia announced guests can attend marriage ceremonies. There will be no standing places or high tables. There must be seating that allows for social distancing. Social distancing must be maintained, including on the dance floor. Visible notifications must be present at the entrance to the facility or immediately after the entrance about compliance with general hygiene measures and physical distance measures. description:
On July 11, 2020, Croatia announced public events may occur and the number of guests is limited to amount of venue space. The organizer has to ensure that at least 3 m² of venue space is planned for each participant. All guests, organizers, and staff are obliged to measure body temperature at the entry point and individuals with a temperature above 37.2 C are not allowed to participate. Also, a person may not participate in any case if:

-Has a household member in self isolation
-Has been abroad in the past 14 days, unless has a negative PCR test not older than 48 hours.
-Had a contact with person infected with SAS-CorV-2 in the past 14 days
-Has one of the following symptoms: high body temperature, cough, lack of air, sore throat, runny nose or loss of smell.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On July 11, 2020, Croatia announced public events may occur and the number of guests is limited to amount of venue space. The organizer has to ensure that at least 3 m² of venue space is planned for each participant. All guests, organizers, and staff are obliged to measure body temperature at the entry point and individuals with a temperature above 37.2 C are not allowed to participate. Also, a person may not participate in any case if:

-Has a household member in self isolation
-Has been abroad in the past 14 days, unless has a negative PCR test not older than 48 hours.
-Had a contact with person infected with SAS-CorV-2 in the past 14 days
-Has one of the following symptoms: high body temperature, cough, lack of air, sore throat, runny nose or loss of smell. UPDATE: Effective July 13, 2020, Croatia announced for gathering of over 100 participants, are obliged to submit a notification about holding the gathering to the territorially competent civil protection service of the Directorate of Civil Protection via e-mail of the county center 112, no later than 48 hours before the planned start of the gathering. The notification must contain:

- the purpose, place, day and time of the gathering
- information about the contact person
- expected number of participants.

Existing measures for public events still apply.

description: Since June 10, 2021, it has been announced in Croatia that citizens who want to visit stadiums and halls to watch sports events will have to calculate the amount of time required for full vaccination. Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are administered in two doses with an interval of three weeks, after which it is necessary to wait another two weeks to receive valid confirmation of Covid. So, just five weeks after taking the first dose. Johnson's vaccine is administered in only one dose. However, after that, it is necessary to wait another 22 days for the formation of antibodies and registration of documents for participation in such mass events.

description: Since March 16, 2020, in Croatia it is recommended to observe social distance in pharmacies and not to create a crowd of people. One person is served at one workplace. After the release of one position, the next person enters the pharmacy. In the queue near the pharmacy, keep a distance of at least 1 meter. When communicating with pharmacy workers, it is necessary to keep a distance of at least 1.5 meters. If possible, it is necessary to use a card form of payment. If you cough and sneeze, cover your mouth and nose with an elbow or a napkin, which you then throw into a trash can with a lid near the pharmacy, and wash your hands. When coughing and sneezing, turn your cheek away from other people.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since March 16, 2020, in Croatia it is recommended to observe social distance in shops and not to create a crowd of people. It is recommended to keep a sufficient distance between other customers, especially at the checkout. Wash your hands thoroughly before and especially after going to the store. Do not touch your mouth, eyes or nose while shopping. Avoid contact with other clients. If you are over 65 years old, do not go to the store. It is better to pay with cards, do not give them to sellers, but put them on POS terminals yourself. If you are signing the form, take your own ballpoint pen with you.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since June 29, 2020, Croatia has recommended that people with disabilities adhere to the same general protection measures as the general population, with a note that they should continue to use all therapy recommended so far in accordance with the doctor's recommendations. It is recommended to avoid close contact (keep a distance of at least 1 meter, preferably two meters) with people who have symptoms of respiratory tract infection, i.e. who have at least one of the following symptoms: fever, cough, sore throat and shortness of breath. Keeping a physical distance and wearing masks is not mandatory in the company of people living in the same household. Hands should be washed frequently and thoroughly with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. When soap and water are unavailable, you can use a disinfectant containing at least 60% alcohol. It should be taken into account that people with disabilities may not be able to wear a mask or perform hand hygiene on their own due to their difficulties. Moreover, other people who are close to a disabled person should more consistently implement all recommended measures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 19, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has activated a new set of measures, according to which stores and establishments which are allowed to continue to operate in accordance with the restrictions are obliged to sell all bulk goods packaged, ensure that there are no crowds when entering shops and facilities, and organize work in such a way as to ensure the greatest possible distance between workers while respecting strict measures of social distance. UPDATE: On 19 March, 2020, Croatian Directorate of Civil Protection has adopted a new decision on measures to restrict social gatherings, work in shops, service activities and the holding of sports and cultural events, except for some stores and establishments. On 18 April, this Decision has been extended until 4 May, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 24, 2020, Croatia announced that training would be allowed for sportsmen and women of I. and II. categories in individual sports that had been issued a decision on categorization issued by the Croatian Olympic Committee, the Croatian Paralympic Committee and the Croatian Sports Association of the Deaf in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Sports. Training was also allowed for sports teams in men's and women's senior competitions that performed at the highest level of competition. The organization of training would be possible only at sports facilities that met such technical and safety conditions that a physical distance of 5 meters could be respected between all athletes, and training could be organized for a maximum of 5 people at the same time including one coach and with a minimum number of technical staff working on a particular facility to which all measures before, during and after training also apply. At the sports facility, all hygiene and safety conditions prescribed by the valid instructions must be ensured during the duration of the measures, for which the city sports associations or communities, or the county headquarters of civil protection, are responsible, and a training record system must be established to ensure contact tracing in case of infection.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 27, 2020, Croatia banned visits to homes for the elderly and infirm. UPDATE: On May 18, 2020, Croatia stated nursing home residents may have visitors and the visitors must comply with epidemiological measures. A maximum of one visitor per room is allowed with strict adherence to measures (mandatory hand disinfection, protective mask), with prior body temperature measurement and signing a statement that the visitor has no symptoms of COVID-19, is not in self-isolation and that his family has no respiratory symptoms. Registration of all visitors on arrival and departure is mandatory.

description: On August 10, 2020, the Croatian Institute of Public Health announced that multiplexes in shopping malls can reopen, five months after closing. At the entrance to the cinema area and in the interior, there should be means for hand disinfection and a notice that hand disinfection is mandatory. When it comes to cinema staff, they must measure their temperature every day before coming to work, and if it is higher than 37.2 degrees, they must not come to work. It is also recommended that visitors take their temperature before coming to the cinema. HZJZ points out that film screening is possible only in halls that can meet conditions such as maintaining physical distance. Also, the number of people who can be in the hall at the same time must be limited, and this number is determined by the organizer according to the size of the space and the type of event. A distance of at least 1.5 meters between visitors is recommended between each seat, as well as when entering, moving and exiting. The exit of visitors should be organized so that they exit one by one, and those closest to the door exit first. Organizers must keep records of visitors, and online ticket sales are encouraged to avoid physical contact.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 26 August 2020, the Head of the national COVID-19 management team and Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic announced that in Croatia's Split-Dalmatia County, starting August 27, wearing masks would become mandatory in bars and restaurants before consuming drinks and food, and owners of restaurants are obliged to supervise their facilities more closely. Gyms would close. The measures were set to last for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: August 24, 2020, School starts in Croatia on September 7, the Education Ministry said on Monday that the main rule is to keep one's distance, not to mix pupils from different classes and to step up hygiene, while face masks will be mandatory only for pupils in higher grades if there is not enough space for them to keep their distance. Pupils should come into contact with a few teachers as possible during one day or period. If there are no other possibilities, it is suggested that the school operates in shifts. For instance, half of the classes could attend school for one week, and the second half next week. In the event of a child exhibiting symptoms, he or she is separated from others and parents come to pick up their child, but there is no need to panic, and an epidemiologist should only be contacted if several children start showing symptoms. If a child tests positive for COVID-19, the entire class or kindergarten group will undergo self-isolation. classes in lower grades of primary school would follow the bubble model so pupils will not leave the classroom, they will have controlled access to the toilet, their teacher will be with them all the time and they will not mix with children from other classes. They will not have to wear face masks, nor will their teacher. Pupils in higher grades of primary schools will only have to wear masks if there is not enough space for them to maintain physical distance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 29, 2020, Science and Education Minister Radovan Fuchs said that closing schools and online classes would be the government's last resort and that he was not considering that measure for now. The school year starts in September, with schools being able to choose the mode of instruction (between physical, mixed and distance learning). Over 92% of schools chose the first mode, i.e. in-classroom, presence-based education. Also, kindergartens are closed because of stuff and positive Covid-19 results.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On November 11, 2020, the National Civil Protection Headquarters, at the proposal of the Civil Protection Headquarters of Sibenik-Knin County, amended the Decision on introducing necessary epidemiological measures for Sibenik-Knin County, which enters into force tomorrow, November 12. The working hours of all types of catering facilities are limited until 10 PM. It is recommended that employers organize work with the greatest possible distance between workers and maintain a minimum physical distance of at least 2 meters, whenever possible.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
target_other: Sibenik-Knin County

description: In view of new instructions by the Croatian Institute for Public Health, since November 22, 2020, employers are required to: prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath; reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible; introduce work from home, when possible given the nature of the work; introduce sliding working hours, where possible; organize work in shifts, i.e. groups, where possible; reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum; regularly ventilate the areas where workers reside.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Starting from November 22, 2020 Croatia announced a strict measure of physical distancing requiring the avoidance of close personal contact at a distance of at least 2 meters indoors and 1.5 meters outdoors. The measure applies until December 15, 2020.

type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: Croatian officials announced new COVID-19 measures to help mitigate the spread of the virus. As of 12:00 AM on November 28, 2020, the following measures will apply until December 21, 2020. It is now mandatory to wear a face covering in the following situations: Retail employees in stores; employees where face to face contact is required; all services that require close contact (hairdressers, salons, etc.); employees of all hospitality services who serve and prepare beverages and food; employees in offices where a physical distance of at least 2 meters cannot be maintained.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Since 12 December, 2020, new restrictions for shops and shopping centres will be implemented, as announced by the Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic. Shops and shopping centres will have to ensure 10 to 20 square metres of space per customer, depending on the size of the net sales area. Under the new decision, shops with a net sales area of less than 10 square metres will be able to admit only one customer at a time. Shops that have a net sales area of 11 to 100 square metres will have to ensure at least 10 square metres of space per customer. Shops with a net sales area of 101 to 200 square metres will have to provide at least 12 square metres of space per customer, those with a net sales area of 201 to 2,000 square metres will have to provide at least 16 square metres, and all shops with a net sales area of more than 2,000 square metres will have to ensure at least 20 square metres of space per customer. In shopping centres, the maximum number of customers will be determined by ensuring at least 16 square metres of space per customer, and all shops and shopping centres will be required to display a notice with the maximum number of customers that can be inside at the same time at the entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Shops that have a net sales area of 11 to 100 square metres will have to ensure at least 10 square metres of space per customer. Shops with a net sales area of 101 to 200 square metres will have to provide at least 12 square metres of space per customer, those with a net sales area of 201 to 2,000 square metres will have to provide at least 16 square metres, and all shops with a net sales area of more than 2,000 square metres will have to ensure at least 20 square metres of space per customer. In shopping centres, the maximum number of customers will be determined by ensuring at least 16 square metres of space per customer, and all shops and shopping centres will be required to display a notice with the maximum number of customers that can be inside at the same time at the entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Shopping Centers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since 12 December, 2020, new restrictions for shops and shopping centres will be implemented, as announced by the Interior Minister Davor Bozinovic. Shops and shopping centres will have to ensure 10 to 20 square metres of space per customer, depending on the size of the net sales area. Under the new decision, shops with a net sales area of less than 10 square metres will be able to admit only one customer at a time. Shops that have a net sales area of 11 to 100 square metres will have to ensure at least 10 square metres of space per customer. Shops with a net sales area of 101 to 200 square metres will have to provide at least 12 square metres of space per customer, those with a net sales area of 201 to 2,000 square metres will have to provide at least 16 square metres, and all shops with a net sales area of more than 2,000 square metres will have to ensure at least 20 square metres of space per customer. In shopping centres, the maximum number of customers will be determined by ensuring at least 16 square metres of space per customer, and all shops and shopping centres will be required to display a notice with the maximum number of customers that can be inside at the same time at the entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Supermarkets/grocery stores
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 18th December 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures limiting gatherings and introducing other necessary epidemiological measures and recommendations to prevent the transmission of the COVID-19 disease through gatherings. The strict physical distancing measure mandates avoiding close personal contact at a distance of at least 2 meters indoors and 1.5 meters outdoors.

description: On December 21, 2020, the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia adopted the Decision on necessary epidemiological measures, according to which there will be limitation of opening hours for bakeries and bread and bakery shops up until 10 PM; prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages from 10 PM to 6 AM; suspension of gyms, fitness centers and sports and recreation centers. The measures also include the suspension of children's and other workshops and organized dance schools; foreign language schools can only perform their activities online or in another way to maintain contact at a distance. Driving schools can hold the theoretical part only online or in another way to maintain contacts at a distance: driving lessons can last a maximum of 45 minutes with mandatory body temperature measurement before entering the car, a break between two candidates must be a minimum of 10 minutes for airing and disinfecting the car, and records of all participants in driving lessons must be kept. The measures are set to last until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In view of new instructions by the Croatian Institute for Public Health, since November 22, 2020, employers are required to: prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath; reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible; introduce work from home, when possible given the nature of the work; introduce sliding working hours, where possible; organize work in shifts, i.e. groups, where possible; reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum; regularly ventilate the areas where workers reside. UPDATE: The necessary epidemiological measures were extended on December 21, 2020, by the Headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia until January 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Croatia announced that from November 28, 2020 to January 31, 2021 wearing protective masks is mandatory in all closed spaces throughout the country. Masks are also mandatory in open spaces where a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters cannot be maintained.

description: As announced by the Croatian government, starting February 15, 2021, bars and restaurants will be allowed to open for outdoor service, and gyms and fitness centres will be permitted to operate but must comply with the epidemiological measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Fitness centres and gyms need to provide at least 20 square metres per person at one time and the premises must be ventilated and equipment needs to be sanitised between users. Dressing rooms and showers must not be used. Casinos and other gambling venues will also be allowed to work until 10 PM; the number of visitors needs to be restricted to ensure at least 7 square metres per person. Hospitality sections of casinos and gaming rooms are to remain shut. Cafes will be permitted to sell drinks to go. All caterers can provide deliveries of food, drinks, beverages and sweets to go. People receiving food and beverages from hospitality establishments must not linger on terraces or in front of the provider’s premises or enter inside. People waiting for deliveries need to keep their distance and wear a mask. The containment measures will be revised on March 1, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On March 31, 2021 the headquarters of the Civil Protection of the Republic of Croatia announced restricting the operation of catering establishments and family farms that provide catering services. Food, drinks, beverages and desserts can only be served on open terraces or other open areas for serving, with strict adherence to prescribed epidemiological measures and special recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute for Public healthcare. Working hours can be set from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. The measures enter into force from April 1st, 2021 until the 15th April, 2021.

description: Since June 17, 2021, organized bus trips in Croatia are allowed in accordance with the epidemiological recommendations of the Croatian Health Authority (HZJZ). They undertake to observe the social distance: the distance between the driver and passengers is not less than 1-2 m, the distance between passengers is not less than 1 m, only 1 person should sit on each row of seats. It is recommended if it is possible to physically separate the driver's cab or leave the first row of seats behind the driver empty, as well as regular ventilation and disinfection of the cabin.

description: As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures: curfew at midnight for all objects, including grocery stores and bakeries. In addition to delivery, drive-in or take-away, restaurants, catering facilities, cafés and bars may also serve guests outside (from 6 AM to 12 AM) and indoors. The number of guests in catering establishments should be limited so that a minimum distance of 1.5 m between guests can be ensured; disinfectants should be made available for the guests. Betting shops, casinos and slot machine clubs are allowed to work from 8 AM to 12 AM, but without serving food/drinks. No alcoholic beverages may be sold between 12 AM and 6 AM. The retail shops are open from 8 AM to 9 PM (until 11 PM at the latest). Masks are compulsory for all employees and customers; all shops must provide disinfectants to customers. Shops are obliged to indicate the maximum number of people allowed at the entrance (based on at least 10m²/person). Hairdressers, massage parlors, locksmiths, etc. are allowed to work in compliance with masks, disinfectants, disinfection of the premises, transparent barriers, etc. The same measures apply to hotels; they should ensure physical distancing of at least 1.5m among guests. Conditions for fitness centres: 20 m² per person, disinfection of the equipment after each use, customers must bring their own towels and mats, showers remain closed, distance rules must be strictly observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures: curfew at midnight for all objects, including grocery stores and bakeries. In addition to delivery, drive-in or take-away, restaurants, catering facilities, cafés and bars may also serve guests outside (from 6 AM to 12 AM) and indoors. The number of guests in catering establishments should be limited so that a minimum distance of 1.5 m between guests can be ensured; disinfectants should be made available for the guests. Betting shops, casinos and slot machine clubs are allowed to work from 8 AM to 12 AM, but without serving food/drinks. No alcoholic beverages may be sold between 12 AM and 6 AM. The retail shops are open from 8 AM to 9 PM (until 11 PM at the latest). Masks are compulsory for all employees and customers; all shops must provide disinfectants to customers. Shops are obliged to indicate the maximum number of people allowed at the entrance (based on at least 10m²/person). Hairdressers, massage parlors, locksmiths, etc. are allowed to work in compliance with masks, disinfectants, disinfection of the premises, transparent barriers, etc. The same measures apply to hotels; they should ensure physical distancing of at least 1.5m among guests. Conditions for fitness centres: 20 m² per person, disinfection of the equipment after each use, customers must bring their own towels and mats, showers remain closed, distance rules must be strictly observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
As of 6 July, 2021, the Croatian government has activated the following measures.
    Employers must prohibit all employees with a high body temperature, breathing difficulties, especially dry cough and shortness of breath, from coming to work; introducing home office, flexitime or work in shifts or groups and to reduce the number of physical meetings whenever possible; post important safety regulations, hygiene and health instructions in the offices; ensure sufficient protective equipment such as gloves, masks, protective suits, helmets, etc. Installation of physical barriers (plexiglass and similar barriers to reduce employee contact with customers); ensuring a place for disinfecting hands; ensuring through better distribution of space and working hours that the minimum distance between employees is guaranteed; meetings only with fewer than 5 people (if possible meeting online, by email or by phone); during breaks, making sure employees do not sit together in groups. Disinfection and cleaning of the work premises (all contact surfaces at least twice a day); regular airing of the rooms, special protection for employees with chronic illnesses and cancer (work from home office), etc. 

Additional regulations for construction: limit all indoor construction meetings to a minimum; divide construction workers into several groups that physically separate the groups; the tasks of building supervision also form groups; draw up evacuation plans; move unneeded people to home office.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Construction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Amendments from June 9, 2021, Hrvatski zavod za javno zdravstvo announced that Schools are open, but with strict guidelines (e.g. splitting classes into two shifts) and some offer a mixture of classroom and online teaching. It includes measures on physical distance, hand hygiene, hand disinfection, organization of space, temperature measurement and symptom monitoring etc.  (published or made editions on July 14)

description: Since August 6, 2021, in Croatia, public transport is allowed to operate at 100%, while maintaining the protection of drivers and passengers, wearing masks in public transport is mandatory. It is necessary to provide a sufficient amount of disinfectants inside the vehicles. Drivers' contacts with travelers should be kept to a minimum. Vehicles must be disinfected regularly.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since August 6, 2021, organized bus trips around the country are allowed in Croatia with 100% bus load while maintaining the protection of the PNV for drivers and passengers. It is also necessary to provide a sufficient amount of disinfectants inside the vehicle. According to the Croatian Border Police, these recommendations must also be followed for non-stop transit trips through Croatia.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From August 6, 2021, theaters and cinemas are allowed to operate in Croatia in compliance with generally established rules of epidemiological hygiene (masks, disinfectants, disinfection of premises, transparent barriers, etc.). Performances should take place outdoors whenever possible. For performances in closed rooms, a minimum distance of 4 seats between visitors (or 4 m2 of space per person) should be provided.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since December 15, 2021 in Croatia, people who appear before a government court or have to attend court sessions do not have to have a Covid certificate. They must comply with all other epidemiological measures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Since January 31, 2022, in Croatia, it is recommended to provide 4 m2 of space for each person present at the ceremony during religious gatherings in mosques and to observe a physical distance between all participants (believers, religious figures) of at least two meters at the entrance and exit, as well as during their stay inside the mosque itself and related places of worship. Members of a joint household are not required to be at a distance of two meters from each other. It is necessary to observe a physical distance of at least 2 m in all directions. If there is such an opportunity, it is recommended to organize and hold religious meetings in the open air with the necessary physical distance of at least 2 meters.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From April 7, 2022 in Croatia, it is recommended to continue using masks whenever there are a large number of people in closed rooms. That is, in all places, regardless of the type of institution, it is still recommended to wear masks with a large crowd of people.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since April 8, 2022, the requirement to wear masks everywhere has been abolished. There is no obligation to wear a mask anywhere except medical and similar institutions. In medical and similar institutions, it is still necessary for all visitors to wear masks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Other public facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since April 9, 2022, parks and zoos have been open in Croatia, but health and safety measures, as well as social distancing rules, are still in effect. Beaches and thermal resorts are open for public use, taking into account that health and safety measures will be applied, as well as any social distancing measures in force at that time. Sports and recreation outdoors and indoors are allowed, swimming pools and tent sports facilities are open. It is recommended to keep a social distance in all places.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since July 4, 2022, travel agencies in Croatia have been recommended to reduce the number of clients. After the entry of the allowed number of clients into the premises, further entry is possible only after the exit of one of the clients. The staff must use face masks covering the nose and mouth during interaction with the client, as well as have a disinfectant at their disposal. It is recommended to implement contactless payment as far as possible.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 4, 2022, in Croatia, camps and campsites are recommended to maintain social distancing at the reception desk. It is necessary to ensure sufficient physical distance between the reception staff and the guest, as well as between the staff themselves. The check-in and check-out process should last no more than 15 minutes (which is the definition of close contact) or, if this is not possible, a barrier should be installed at the reception desk that provides the necessary sanitary distance. There should also be enough space in the reception area to comply with physical distancing measures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 4, 2022, in Croatia, camps and campsites are recommended to serve guests at the table whenever possible. In the case of a buffet, where technically possible, it is recommended that meals and drinks be served in such a way that guests cannot take food on their own if it is not distributed in portions. During the stay at the facility, and especially during the buffet, guests are advised to observe a physical distance of 1.5 meters, except for members of the same family, in which case this measure is not required. When placing an order, it is necessary to observe a physical distance of at least 1.5 m between customers waiting in line. You can order food or drinks at the bar without stopping, but you are not allowed to stay at the bar. In addition, it is possible to serve standing guests if they keep a physical distance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
